title: Israel to Open Gaza Border After Finding Hostage's Body
summary: Israel says it will reopen an important border crossing between Gaza and Egypt, but only after they find the body of a missing Israeli police officer named Ran Gvili. The crossing, called Rafah, has been closed since May 2024 when Israeli forces took control. It was supposed to open as part of a ceasefire agreement between Israel and Hamas, but Israel made it a condition that Hamas helps return the officer's body. Israeli soldiers are now searching in northern Gaza, near Gaza City, to find his remains. They think he might be buried in a cemetery. Once the search is done, Israel will open the crossing for people to walk through, but with strict checks. The United States is helping to make peace between the two sides. This is important because opening the crossing could help people in Gaza get supplies and travel more easily.

background_read: This article is about a conflict between Israel and Hamas in Gaza. Gaza is a small area next to Israel and Egypt, where many Palestinians live. Israel and Hamas have been fighting, and a ceasefire was agreed to stop the violence. Hostages are people taken during conflicts, and finding them is very important for families and peace. Border crossings like Rafah help people move and get food and medicine. The United States often tries to help solve problems in this region to bring peace.
